elements.content: Two crystalline zinc phosphates, formulated as Zn­(HPO4)­(dl-C5H9NO2) (SCU-3) and Zn­(HPO4)­(C2H5NO2) (SCU-10), were prepared under surfactant-thermal conditions using amino acids as structure-directing agents. Different from traditional zeolites with 4-connected nets, the two compounds have different 3-connected nets related to zeolite ABW. Powder second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement shows that SCU-10 is a nonlinear optically active solid with an SHG efficiency about 1.4 times that of KH2PO4.
elements.clean_text: Two crystalline zinc phosphates, formulated as Zn(HPO4)(dl-C5H9NO2) (SCU-3) and Zn(HPO4)(C2H5NO2) (SCU-10), were prepared under surfactant-thermal conditions using amino acids as structure-directing agents. Different from traditional zeolites with 4-connected nets, the two compounds have different 3-connected nets related to zeolite ABW. Powder second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement shows that SCU-10 is a nonlinear optically active solid with an SHG efficiency about 1.4 times that of KH2PO4.

elements.content:
A chiral zinc phosphate with a 3-connected srs net was prepared under surfactant-thermal conditions and displays a moderate SHG efficiency and blue luminescence under UV light.

Open-framework metal phosphates have become increasingly important because of their diverse structures and appealing properties such as photoluminescence, photochromism, catalysis, proton conduction, and ion exchange. These inorganic materials are usually prepared under hydrothermal and solvothermal conditions using tetralkylammoniums, amines, metal complexes, and alkaline ions as charge-compensating structure-directing agents. In comparison, the structure-directing roles of amino acids have rarely been studied, although amino acids possess several unusual features, such as biological functions, variable charges, and chirality. On the limited evidence so far, it seems that amino acids always serve as terminal ligands in metal phosphate systems. We envision that the strong covalent interactions between amino acids and metal centers may be unfavorable for defect repair during the crystallization process and often lead to microcrystalline powder samples. To obtain good-quality single crystals, the development of new synthetic strategies that could hinder the bonding between amino acids and metal ions is therefore highly desirable.
elements.clean_text:
A chiral zinc phosphate with a 3-connected srs net was prepared under surfactant-thermal conditions and displays a moderate SHG efficiency and blue luminescence under UV light.

Open-framework metal phosphates have become increasingly important because of their diverse structures and appealing properties such as photoluminescence, photochromism, catalysis, proton conduction, and ion exchange. These inorganic materials are usually prepared under hydrothermal and solvothermal conditions using tetralkylammoniums, amines, metal complexes, and alkaline ions as charge-compensating structure-directing agents. In comparison, the structure-directing roles of amino acids have rarely been studied, although amino acids possess several unusual features, such as biological functions, variable charges, and chirality. On the limited evidence so far, it seems that amino acids always serve as terminal ligands in metal phosphate systems. We envision that the strong covalent interactions between amino acids and metal centers may be unfavorable for defect repair during the crystallization process and often lead to microcrystalline powder samples. To obtain good-quality single crystals, the development of new synthetic strategies that could hinder the bonding between amino acids and metal ions is therefore highly desirable.

elements.content: Surfactant-thermal synthesis, using a surfactant as the solvent and sometimes the pore filler, is of current interest in the preparation of new functional materials. This synthetic method can avoid high reaction pressure, control phase transformations, and purify mixed phases of crystalline solids. Since the pioneering work reporting the growth of crystalline thioarsenates in surfactants, a number of new metal chalcogenides and metal–organic frameworks were prepared under surfactant-thermal conditions. A notable example is the semiconducting selenidostannate [DBNH]2[Sn3Se7]·PEG encapsulating poly­(ethylene glycol) (PEG) chains within its honeycomb-like nanochannels. Very recently, a luminescent zeolite-like galloborate was synthesized using PEG as the reaction medium. These successful progresses encourage us to extend the surfactant-thermal method to the preparation of new metal phosphates templated by amino acids.
elements.clean_text: Surfactant-thermal synthesis, using a surfactant as the solvent and sometimes the pore filler, is of current interest in the preparation of new functional materials. This synthetic method can avoid high reaction pressure, control phase transformations, and purify mixed phases of crystalline solids. Since the pioneering work reporting the growth of crystalline thioarsenates in surfactants, a number of new metal chalcogenides and metal-organic frameworks were prepared under surfactant-thermal conditions. A notable example is the semiconducting selenidostannate [DBNH]2[Sn3Se7]⋅PEG encapsulating poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) chains within its honeycomb-like nanochannels. Very recently, a luminescent zeolite-like galloborate was synthesized using PEG as the reaction medium. These successful progresses encourage us to extend the surfactant-thermal method to the preparation of new metal phosphates templated by amino acids.

elements.content: A large variety of surfactants with multiple properties create many synthetic possibilities in metal phosphate systems. In this work, we choose PEG as the reaction medium because it is a cheap and biodegradable polymer with a low melting point. More importantly, the ability of PEG to coordinate with metal ions may hinder the covalent interactions between amino acids and metal ions. As a result, the rate of nucleation and crystal growth for amino acid templated metal phosphates will be modulated by PEG. This synthetic strategy is similar to that adopted for the solvothermal crystallization of zirconium-based metal–organic frameworks, in which the addition of a modulator (e.g., benzoic acid) can greatly improve the crystallinity of as-prepared porous materials.
elements.clean_text: A large variety of surfactants with multiple properties create many synthetic possibilities in metal phosphate systems. In this work, we choose PEG as the reaction medium because it is a cheap and biodegradable polymer with a low melting point. More importantly, the ability of PEG to coordinate with metal ions may hinder the covalent interactions between amino acids and metal ions. As a result, the rate of nucleation and crystal growth for amino acid templated metal phosphates will be modulated by PEG. This synthetic strategy is similar to that adopted for the solvothermal crystallization of zirconium-based metal-organic frameworks, in which the addition of a modulator (e.g., benzoic acid) can greatly improve the crystallinity of as-prepared porous materials.

elements.content: Here we report the surfactant-thermal synthesis of two amino acid-templated zinc phosphates, formulated as Zn­(HPO4)­(dl-C5H9NO2) (SCU-3) and Zn­(HPO4)­(C2H5NO2) (SCU-10), adopting PEG as the reaction medium. Structural analysis reveals that SCU-3 has a layered structure templated by proline and SCU-10 has a three-dimensional structure templated by glycine. The two compounds have 3-connected topologies (i.e., an fes net for SCU-3 and an srs net for SCU-10) related to zeolite ABW. It is worth noting that the chiral srs net is rarely observed in open-framework inorganic solids. Powder second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement shows that SCU-10 is a phase-matchable nonlinear optically active solid with an SHG efficiency about 1.4 times that of KH2PO4 (KDP). Under UV-light irradiation, this compound exhibits blue luminescence.
elements.clean_text: Here we report the surfactant-thermal synthesis of two amino acid-templated zinc phosphates, formulated as Zn(HPO4)(dl-C5H9NO2) (SCU-3) and Zn(HPO4)(C2H5NO2) (SCU-10), adopting PEG as the reaction medium. Structural analysis reveals that SCU-3 has a layered structure templated by proline and SCU-10 has a three-dimensional structure templated by glycine. The two compounds have 3-connected topologies (i.e., an fes net for SCU-3 and an srs net for SCU-10) related to zeolite ABW. It is worth noting that the chiral srs net is rarely observed in open-framework inorganic solids. Powder second-harmonic-generation (SHG) measurement shows that SCU-10 is a phase-matchable nonlinear optically active solid with an SHG efficiency about 1.4 times that of KH2PO4 (KDP). Under UV-light irradiation, this compound exhibits blue luminescence.

elements.content: In a typical surfactant-thermal synthesis, a mixture of ZnO (0.081 g), l-proline (0.231 g), H3PO4 (85%, 0.068 mL), and PEG-400 (2.0 mL) was heated in a Teflon-coated steel autoclave at 150 °C for 7 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of SCU-3 were separated from the resulting product by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air (22% yield based on zinc). SCU-10 was prepared from a mixture of ZnO (0.081 g), glycine (0.078 g), H3PO4 (85%, 0.068 mL), and PEG-200 (2.0 mL), following a reaction procedure similar to that of SCU-3 (30% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the two compounds was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that the two compounds remained stable up to 210 and 270 °C, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In a typical surfactant-thermal synthesis, a mixture of ZnO (0.081 g), l-proline (0.231 g), H3PO4 (85%, 0.068 mL), and PEG-400 (2.0 mL) was heated in a Teflon-coated steel autoclave at 150 °C for 7 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of SCU-3 were separated from the resulting product by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air (22% yield based on zinc). SCU-10 was prepared from a mixture of ZnO (0.081 g), glycine (0.078 g), H3PO4 (85%, 0.068 mL), and PEG-200 (2.0 mL), following a reaction procedure similar to that of SCU-3 (30% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the two compounds was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that the two compounds remained stable up to 210 and 270 °C, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD analysis revealed that SCU-3 has a layered structure decorated with proline molecules. The asymmetric unit consists of one HPO4 unit, one zinc atom, and one zwitterionic proline molecule. Each zinc atom connects three HPO4 units and vice versa. The linkage between zinc atoms and HPO4 units produces undulated layers parallel to the bc plane. The zinc phosphate layer has a 3-connected fes net containing 4-ring and 8-ring windows (a). They are packed along the [100] direction in an ABAB sequence. Zwitterionic proline molecules attach on the surface of these layers through Zn–O bonds as terminal ligands (b). It should be noted that SCU-3 is achiral because the amino acids are racemized during long-time crystallization at high temperature. This compound could also be prepared by the use of dl-proline in the reaction system. A low-temperature environment may be beneficial for the formation of homochiral structures. For example, Li and co-workers reported the synthesis of a homochiral zinc phosphate, ZnPO-CJ57, using l-histidine as the structure-directing agent at 100 °C for 7 days. However, our attempts to prepare homochiral SCU-3 were not successful by decreasing the crystallization temperature below 150 °C.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal XRD analysis revealed that SCU-3 has a layered structure decorated with proline molecules. The asymmetric unit consists of one HPO4 unit, one zinc atom, and one zwitterionic proline molecule. Each zinc atom connects three HPO4 units and vice versa. The linkage between zinc atoms and HPO4 units produces undulated layers parallel to the bc plane. The zinc phosphate layer has a 3-connected fes net containing 4-ring and 8-ring windows (a). They are packed along the [100] direction in an ABAB sequence. Zwitterionic proline molecules attach on the surface of these layers through Zn-O bonds as terminal ligands (b). It should be noted that SCU-3 is achiral because the amino acids are racemized during long-time crystallization at high temperature. This compound could also be prepared by the use of dl-proline in the reaction system. A low-temperature environment may be beneficial for the formation of homochiral structures. For example, Li and co-workers reported the synthesis of a homochiral zinc phosphate, ZnPO-CJ57, using l-histidine as the structure-directing agent at 100 °C for 7 days. However, our attempts to prepare homochiral SCU-3 were not successful by decreasing the crystallization temperature below 150 °C.

elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the zinc phosphate layer with 4-ring and 8-ring windows. (b) Side view of the layered structure of SCU-3 decorated with proline molecules.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Polyhedral representation of the zinc phosphate layer with 4-ring and 8-ring windows. (b) Side view of the layered structure of SCU-3 decorated with proline molecules.

elements.content: SCU-10 has a three-dimensional structure templated by glycine (a). The asymmetric unit consists of 10 non-hydrogen atoms, of which one zinc atom and one phosphorus atom are crystallographically independent. The zinc atom is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from three HPO4 unis and one glycine molecule. The phosphorus atom makes three P–O–Zn linkages to adjacent zinc atoms, with the fourth vertex occupied by a terminal hydroxyl group. The strict alternation of ZnO4 and HPO4 tetrahedra gives rise to a three-dimensional structure. At first glance, it seems that the framework has 8-ring channels. Careful analysis of the structure reveals that it only contains 10-ring windows (b). The zwitterionic glycine molecules attach to the framework through Zn–O bonds as terminal ligands. Considering zinc atoms and phosphorus atoms as 3-connected nodes, the structure can be simplified as an srs net.
elements.clean_text: SCU-10 has a three-dimensional structure templated by glycine (a). The asymmetric unit consists of 10 non-hydrogen atoms, of which one zinc atom and one phosphorus atom are crystallographically independent. The zinc atom is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from three HPO4 unis and one glycine molecule. The phosphorus atom makes three P-O-Zn linkages to adjacent zinc atoms, with the fourth vertex occupied by a terminal hydroxyl group. The strict alternation of ZnO4 and HPO4 tetrahedra gives rise to a three-dimensional structure. At first glance, it seems that the framework has 8-ring channels. Careful analysis of the structure reveals that it only contains 10-ring windows (b). The zwitterionic glycine molecules attach to the framework through Zn-O bonds as terminal ligands. Considering zinc atoms and phosphorus atoms as 3-connected nodes, the structure can be simplified as an srs net.

elements.content: (a) Three-dimensional structure of SCU-10 viewed along the [100] direction. (b) Polyhedral representation of a 10-ring window in SCU-10. (c) Side view of the helical channels constructed from corner-sharing ZnO4 and HPO4 tetrahedra.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Three-dimensional structure of SCU-10 viewed along the [100] direction. (b) Polyhedral representation of a 10-ring window in SCU-10. (c) Side view of the helical channels constructed from corner-sharing ZnO4 and HPO4 tetrahedra.

elements.content: SCU-10 features an intrinsically chiral framework. Viewed along the [100], [010], and [001] directions, the structure displays multidirectional helical channels (c). Prior to this work, multidirectional helical channels are also present in some open-framework inorganic solids, such as ZnPO3-n (n = 1–3), [{Zn2(HPO4)4}­{Co­(dien)2}]·H3O, and BeHPO-1. However, these inorganic solids are not chiral because of the coexistence of both right- and left-handed helical channels. In the case of SCU-10, each single crystal contains only right- or left-handed helical channels. The chirality of SCU-10 is produced through the spatial organization of achiral building blocks, which is different from that of ZnPO-CJ57 with its chirality transformed from l-histidine.
elements.clean_text: SCU-10 features an intrinsically chiral framework. Viewed along the [100], [010], and [001] directions, the structure displays multidirectional helical channels (c). Prior to this work, multidirectional helical channels are also present in some open-framework inorganic solids, such as ZnPO3-n (n = 1-3), [{Zn2(HPO4)4}{Co(dien)2}]⋅H3O, and BeHPO-1. However, these inorganic solids are not chiral because of the coexistence of both right- and left-handed helical channels. In the case of SCU-10, each single crystal contains only right- or left-handed helical channels. The chirality of SCU-10 is produced through the spatial organization of achiral building blocks, which is different from that of ZnPO-CJ57 with its chirality transformed from l-histidine.

elements.content: The 3-connected net of SCU-10 is rare in open-framework inorganic solids. It is well-known that zeolites and aluminophosphate molecular sieves usually have 4-connected frameworks constructed from corner-sharing tetrahedral building units. Recently, the synthesis of open-framework materials containing 3-connected building units, such as HPO3 and BO3, has attracted considerable interest. It has been proposed that 3-connected building blocks are favorable for the formation of open-framework structures with large pores. An illustrative example is the 3,4-connected zinc phosphite ZnHPO-CJ1 containing extralarge 24-ring channels. However, the 3-connected building blocks, when used, often give rise to low-dimensional structures, such as one-dimensional ladders and two-dimensional layers (e.g., hcb and fes nets). Three-dimensional inorganic solids built solely from 3-connected building blocks are quite rare. The limited examples include NaTi2(PS4)3, ABPO4F (A = NH4 +, Rb+, Cs+), SCU-18, and SCU-36. The discovery of SCU-10 adds a new member in the family of three-dimensional inorganic solids with 3-connected nets.
elements.clean_text: The 3-connected net of SCU-10 is rare in open-framework inorganic solids. It is well-known that zeolites and aluminophosphate molecular sieves usually have 4-connected frameworks constructed from corner-sharing tetrahedral building units. Recently, the synthesis of open-framework materials containing 3-connected building units, such as HPO3 and BO3, has attracted considerable interest. It has been proposed that 3-connected building blocks are favorable for the formation of open-framework structures with large pores. An illustrative example is the 3,4-connected zinc phosphite ZnHPO-CJ1 containing extralarge 24-ring channels. However, the 3-connected building blocks, when used, often give rise to low-dimensional structures, such as one-dimensional ladders and two-dimensional layers (e.g., hcb and fes nets). Three-dimensional inorganic solids built solely from 3-connected building blocks are quite rare. The limited examples include NaTi2(PS4)3, ABPO4F (A = NH4 +, Rb+, Cs+), SCU-18, and SCU-36. The discovery of SCU-10 adds a new member in the family of three-dimensional inorganic solids with 3-connected nets.

elements.content: It is of great interest to examine how amino acids direct the formation of different metal phosphate structures. Unlike conventional structure-directing agents residing within the pores of metal phosphates, amino acids readily coordinate with metal ions as terminal ligands. These organic species can be regarded as “chemical scissors” to reduce M–O–P linkages in open-framework metal phosphates. When a zeolite-like metal phosphate is scissored by amino acids, a variety of low-dimensional or interrupted structures are potentially accessed. For example, clusterlike, chainlike, ladderlike, layered, and srs nets can be conceptually cut from a metal phosphate with zeolitic ABW topology, as shown in . Experimentally, two of the possibilities have now been realized in zinc phosphate systems: SCU-3 corresponding to the fes-type layer and SCU-10 to the srs net. The clusterlike and ladderlike structures were previously obtained in the zinc phosphates ZnPO-CJ58 and SCU-4 using histidine and alanine, respectively, as the “chemical scissors”. Other metal phosphate structures, such as the linear chain and hcb net, remain to be discovered in amino acid-templated zinc phosphate systems.
elements.clean_text: It is of great interest to examine how amino acids direct the formation of different metal phosphate structures. Unlike conventional structure-directing agents residing within the pores of metal phosphates, amino acids readily coordinate with metal ions as terminal ligands. These organic species can be regarded as "chemical scissors" to reduce M-O-P linkages in open-framework metal phosphates. When a zeolite-like metal phosphate is scissored by amino acids, a variety of low-dimensional or interrupted structures are potentially accessed. For example, clusterlike, chainlike, ladderlike, layered, and srs nets can be conceptually cut from a metal phosphate with zeolitic ABW topology, as shown in . Experimentally, two of the possibilities have now been realized in zinc phosphate systems: SCU-3 corresponding to the fes-type layer and SCU-10 to the srs net. The clusterlike and ladderlike structures were previously obtained in the zinc phosphates ZnPO-CJ58 and SCU-4 using histidine and alanine, respectively, as the "chemical scissors". Other metal phosphate structures, such as the linear chain and hcb net, remain to be discovered in amino acid-templated zinc phosphate systems.

elements.content: Topological representation of several low-dimensional and interrupted structures that are related to zeolitic ABW.
elements.clean_text: 3  Topological representation of several low-dimensional and interrupted structures that are related to zeolitic ABW.

elements.content: The intrinsically chiral structure of SCU-10 is interesting and prompts us to study its nonlinear-optical (NLO) property. SHG measurement was performed on ground crystals of SCU-10 at room temperature using the notable NLO material KDP as a reference. As shown in a, the SHG signals increase gradually with an increase of the particle size of sieved samples and then tend to be constant. According to the rule proposed by Kurtz and Perry, SCU-10 is a phase-matchable NLO solid. The SHG efficiency of SCU-10 is about 1.4 times that of KDP with the same particle size of 150–210 μm. Upon excitation at 365 nm, SCU-10 exhibits blue luminescence with a strong band at 465 nm and a shoulder a 525 nm (b). Such photoluminescence is usually assigned to the presence of lattice defects in activator-free metal phosphates.
elements.clean_text: The intrinsically chiral structure of SCU-10 is interesting and prompts us to study its nonlinear-optical (NLO) property. SHG measurement was performed on ground crystals of SCU-10 at room temperature using the notable NLO material KDP as a reference. As shown in a, the SHG signals increase gradually with an increase of the particle size of sieved samples and then tend to be constant. According to the rule proposed by Kurtz and Perry, SCU-10 is a phase-matchable NLO solid. The SHG efficiency of SCU-10 is about 1.4 times that of KDP with the same particle size of 150-210 μm. Upon excitation at 365 nm, SCU-10 exhibits blue luminescence with a strong band at 465 nm and a shoulder a 525 nm (b). Such photoluminescence is usually assigned to the presence of lattice defects in activator-free metal phosphates.

elements.content: (a) SHG measurements on ground crystals of SCU-10 (blue triangles) using KDP (purple solid circles) as a reference. (b) Photoluminescent emission spectrum of SCU-10 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-10 under UV light (λ = 365 nm).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) SHG measurements on ground crystals of SCU-10 (blue triangles) using KDP (purple solid circles) as a reference. (b) Photoluminescent emission spectrum of SCU-10 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-10 under UV light (λ = 365 nm).

elements.content: In summary, two new amino acid-templated zinc phosphates were prepared using PEG as the reaction medium. They have different 3-connected nets (i.e., fes and srs nets) related to zeolite ABW. The chiral srs net is rare in metal phosphate chemistry and shows a moderate SHG efficiency. The present work demonstrates that amino acids may act as “chemical scissors” to cut different low-dimensional or interrupted structures from zeolitic frameworks. We believe that the amino acid-templated approach can be readily extended to synthesize other functional inorganic solids, such as metal phosphites and borates, under surfactant-thermal conditions.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two new amino acid-templated zinc phosphates were prepared using PEG as the reaction medium. They have different 3-connected nets (i.e., fes and srs nets) related to zeolite ABW. The chiral srs net is rare in metal phosphate chemistry and shows a moderate SHG efficiency. The present work demonstrates that amino acids may act as "chemical scissors" to cut different low-dimensional or interrupted structures from zeolitic frameworks. We believe that the amino acid-templated approach can be readily extended to synthesize other functional inorganic solids, such as metal phosphites and borates, under surfactant-thermal conditions.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Crystal data for SCU-3: C5H10NO6PZn, M = 276.48, monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15), a = 18.7569(3) Å, b = 8.9378(2) Å, c = 10.7986(2) Å, β = 98.016(2)°, V = 1792.66(5) Å3, Z = 8, D c = 2.049 g cm–3, μ = 6.633 mm–1, 4746 reflections measured, 1602 unique (R int = 0.0295). Final wR 2 (all data) = 0.1291, and final R 1 = 0.0446. Crystal data for SCU-10: C2H6NO6PZn, M = 236.42, orthorhombic, space group P212121 (No. 19), a = 7.4063(1) Å, b = 9.0555(2) Å, c = 9.3690(2) Å, V = 628.36(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.499 g cm–3, μ = 7.862 mm–1, Flack parameter = −0.08(6), 2032 reflections measured, 1055 unique (R int = 0.0356). Final wR 2 (all data) = 0.1171, and final R 1 = 0.0457.

cln_elements.content: In a typical surfactant-thermal synthesis, a mixture of ZnO (0.081 g), l-proline (0.231 g), H3PO4 (85%, 0.068 mL), and PEG-400 (2.0 mL) was heated in a Teflon-coated steel autoclave at 150 °C for 7 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of SCU-3 were separated from the resulting product by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air (22% yield based on zinc). SCU-10 was prepared from a mixture of ZnO (0.081 g), glycine (0.078 g), H3PO4 (85%, 0.068 mL), and PEG-200 (2.0 mL), following a reaction procedure similar to that of SCU-3 (30% yield based on zinc). The phase purity of the two compounds was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) revealed that the two compounds remained stable up to 210 and 270 °C, respectively.

cln_elements.content:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Crystal data for SCU-3: C5H10NO6PZn, M = 276.48, monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15), a = 18.7569(3) Å, b = 8.9378(2) Å, c = 10.7986(2) Å, β = 98.016(2)°, V = 1792.66(5) Å3, Z = 8, D c = 2.049 g cm–3, μ = 6.633 mm–1, 4746 reflections measured, 1602 unique (R int = 0.0295). Final wR 2 (all data) = 0.1291, and final R 1 = 0.0446. Crystal data for SCU-10: C2H6NO6PZn, M = 236.42, orthorhombic, space group P212121 (No. 19), a = 7.4063(1) Å, b = 9.0555(2) Å, c = 9.3690(2) Å, V = 628.36(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.499 g cm–3, μ = 7.862 mm–1, Flack parameter = −0.08(6), 2032 reflections measured, 1055 unique (R int = 0.0356). Final wR 2 (all data) = 0.1171, and final R 1 = 0.0457.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Crystal data for SCU-3: C5H10NO6PZn, M = 276.48, monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15), a = 18.7569(3) Å, b = 8.9378(2) Å, c = 10.7986(2) Å, β = 98.016(2)°, V = 1792.66(5) Å3, Z = 8, D c = 2.049 g cm-3, μ = 6.633 mm-1, 4746 reflections measured, 1602 unique (R int = 0.0295). Final wR 2 (all data) = 0.1291, and final R 1 = 0.0446. Crystal data for SCU-10: C2H6NO6PZn, M = 236.42, orthorhombic, space group P212121 (No. 19), a = 7.4063(1) Å, b = 9.0555(2) Å, c = 9.3690(2) Å, V = 628.36(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 2.499 g cm-3, μ = 7.862 mm-1, Flack parameter = -0.08(6), 2032 reflections measured, 1055 unique (R int = 0.0356). Final wR 2 (all data) = 0.1171, and final R 1 = 0.0457.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the zinc phosphate layer with 4-ring and 8-ring windows. (b) Side view of the layered structure of SCU-3 decorated with proline molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Polyhedral representation of the zinc phosphate layer with 4-ring and 8-ring windows. (b) Side view of the layered structure of SCU-3 decorated with proline molecules.

cln_elements.content: (a) Three-dimensional structure of SCU-10 viewed along the [100] direction. (b) Polyhedral representation of a 10-ring window in SCU-10. (c) Side view of the helical channels constructed from corner-sharing ZnO4 and HPO4 tetrahedra.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Three-dimensional structure of SCU-10 viewed along the [100] direction. (b) Polyhedral representation of a 10-ring window in SCU-10. (c) Side view of the helical channels constructed from corner-sharing ZnO4 and HPO4 tetrahedra.

cln_elements.content: Topological representation of several low-dimensional and interrupted structures that are related to zeolitic ABW.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Topological representation of several low-dimensional and interrupted structures that are related to zeolitic ABW.

cln_elements.content: (a) SHG measurements on ground crystals of SCU-10 (blue triangles) using KDP (purple solid circles) as a reference. (b) Photoluminescent emission spectrum of SCU-10 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-10 under UV light (λ = 365 nm).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) SHG measurements on ground crystals of SCU-10 (blue triangles) using KDP (purple solid circles) as a reference. (b) Photoluminescent emission spectrum of SCU-10 at room temperature. Inset: Photograph of crystals of SCU-10 under UV light (λ = 365 nm).

metadata.title: Surfactant-Thermal Synthesis of Amino Acid-Templated Zinc Phosphates with 3‑Connected Nets Related to Zeolite ABW
